Record.Value: Rocketry
A rocket science refresher.
Getting Started in Rocketry
Before you can launch a rocket, you need to build a launch pad.
Follow the walkway to the launch site and pick up the {THING:ItemKitStructureLaunchPad} on the white crate.
Build the {THING:StructureLaunchPad} in the highlighted position.
Building the Launch Platform
The {THING:StructureLaunchPad} is the rocket's main charging point and connects to all of the rocket's modules.
Weld {THING:ItemSteelSheets} to the {THING:StructureLaunchPad}.
Attach electronics to the {THING:StructureLaunchPad}.
Rocket Engines
The next part of the rocket is the {THING:StructureModularRocketEngine01}. This turns fuel into thrust, allowing the rocket to take off and escape the planet's gravity.
Pick up the {THING:ItemKitStructureModularRocketEngine01} from the crate on the left.
Build the {THING:StructureModularRocketEngine01} in the highlighted spot.
Rocket Engineering 101
Contrary to popular belief, building a rocket engine is as easy as 1,2,3. You just need some steel, plastic, and electronics.
Weld {THING:ItemSteelSheets} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketEngine01}
Weld {THING:ItemPlasticSheets} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketEngine01}
Attach {THING:ItemElectronicParts} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketEngine01}
Fuel Tanks
The Fuel Tank is the next module of the rocket. You can have multiple Fuel Tank modules on a rocket to carry more fuel. This will allow you to take more cargo with you.
Pick up {THING:ItemKitStructureModularRocketFueltank01} from the crate on the left.
Build the {THING:StructureModularRocketFueltank01} in the highlighted position.
Fuel Tanks
Rockets in Stationeers use the same fuel as other items requiring flammable gas such as the Welder or Gas Generator. A 2:1 ratio of Volatiles and Oxygen provides the cleanest burn.
Attach {THING:ItemKitTank} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketFueltank01}
Weld {THING:ItemSteelSheets} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketFueltank01}
Attach {THING:ItemElectronicParts} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketFueltank01}
Cargo Module
The Cargo Module allows you to take equipment and devices with you to your next destination. You can build more than one cargo module, but they must be above the fuel tanks.
Pick up the {THING:ItemKitStructureModularRocketCargo01} from the lefthand crate
Build the {THING:StructureModularRocketCargo01} in the highlighted position
Building The Cargo Module
Building the Cargo Module is similar to other modules. Building multiple modules will add more weight to the rocket and will require more fuel to exit the planet's gravitational field.
Weld {THING:ItemSteelSheets} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketCargo01}
Weld {THING:ItemPlasticSheets} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketCargo01}
Attach {THING:ItemElectronicParts} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketCargo01}
Command Module
The Command Module is the final part of the Rocket, and its central control point. It is also the module that controls the final destination of the rocket.
Pick up the {THING:ItemKitStructureModularRocketCommand01} from the white crate on the left
Place the {THING:StructureModularRocketCommand01} in the highlighted position
Building The Command Module

Equipped with outer shell heat shielding and a tempered alumino-silicate glass pane, the module can safely leave and re-enter the atmosphere of a planet with no risk to Stationeers inside. It is fully insulated, with an active air conditioning unit and carbon scrubbers to maintain optimum temperature and breathability.
Weld {THING:ItemSteelSheets} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketCommand01}
Weld {THING:ItemPlasticSheets} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketCommand01}
Attach {THING:ItemElectronicParts} to the {THING:StructureModularRocketCommand01}
Fuel Up

It's time to fuel up the rocket. A pre-prepared fuel mix has been added to the large fuel tank. You will need to complete the piping to the newly built rocket fuel module. The command module takes oxygen but it is not essential, as you are in a suit and will have sufficient reserves for the flight.
Build a {THING:StructureInsulatedPipeStraight} in the highlighted position
Build a {THING:StructureInsulatedPipeCorner} in the highlighted position
No Power
There seems to be no power to the rocket. Check the {THING:StructureAreaPowerControl} found behind the elevator.
Turn on the {THING:StructureAreaPowerControl}
Setting a Destination

Before you launch, you will want to program the flight computer with a valid destination - or else you may end up in the middle of nowhere. In this case, we want to travel to Mimas, one of Saturn's moons. Do this by writing the Planet ID to the Command Module using a logic writer.
Open the Stationpedia
Navigate to the World Travel Section, click on "Travel", and read about how to set destinations then click on the Mimas Coordinates: -712314497 to copy it to your clipboard
Pick up the {THING:ItemLabeller} found in the lefthand crate.
Set the {THING:StructureLogicMemory} to the Mimas Coordinates: -712314497 using the {THING:ItemLabeller}.
Set the input value on the {THING:StructureLogicWriter} to {THING:StructureLogicMemory} using a {THING:ItemScrewdriver}
Set the output value on the {THING:StructureLogicWriter} to {THING:StructureLaunchPad} using a {THING:ItemScrewdriver}
Set the LogicType value on the {THING:StructureLogicWriter} to "Setting" using a {THING:ItemScrewdriver}
Finally, turn on the {THING:StructureLogicWriter}. Any previous steps should check off.
The Fuel Up Valve
The last part of preparing the rocket is to turn on the fuel valve and fill rocket's fuel tank.
Open the fuel valve, located above the logic room.
Time for Lift Off
It's time to lift off! Take the elevator up to the top floor, Once the rocket is fulled and ready you can enter the Command Module. Then hit the LAUNCH button.
Launch the rocket
